summary: Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a type of cancer that causes lesions (abnormal tissue) to grow in different parts of the body, including the skin, lymph nodes, mucous membranes, and other organs. These lesions are usually red or purple and are made of cancer cells, new blood vessels, and blood cells. KS can occur in multiple places simultaneously and is caused by infection with human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), in individuals with weakened immune systems.
causes: Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) infection in combination with immune suppression
risk_factors: Weakened immune systems due to HIV/AIDS
Weakened immune systems due to immunosuppressive medications after organ transplant
Being a young man in Africa
Sexual transmission of KSHV (e.g., deep kissing)
symptoms: Red, purple, or brown skin lesions (nodules or blotches)
Lesions on legs and feet (ankles, soles)
Lesions in the mouth (hard palate, gums)
Lesions in the stomach or intestines
Painful swelling due to lymph and blood flow blockage
diagnosis: Detection of KSHV protein LANA in tumor cells
treatments: Adjusting dose or switching immunosuppressive medications (for iatrogenic KS)
Injections of chemotherapy into the lesion
Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) (for AIDS-associated KS)
